author: kdenhartog
content: Here's a bit of a conundrum - I was just reviewing the Sign in With Ethereum spec (EIP-4361)  and realized that they reference ISO 8601 date format and was thinking that would be a good spec that should be referenced out to, but it's a paid spec so not really possible. Does anyone know of another free place I could link out to in order to normatively reference that spec which would also be a stable link?

author: kdenhartog
content: Alternatively <@689161464829050960> <@301186049323958275> <@543900561460822016> this was one of the clear lines we didn't want to cross was requiring links that need to be paid for which I agree with. Would it be better to just reference this by name like they've already done https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-4361#message-field-descriptions and not link? It seems there's sufficient amount of docs available for most devs to figure out what an ISO 8601 date is, but not ideal for spec writing to leave this up to the reader to assume.

author: kdenhartog
content: I was just trying to help the Spruce team out with a few details so it can go to final call and noticed this so wanted to get some other key people's opinion who weighed in on that topic.

author: samwilsn
content: I think the best way to do it would've been to put the subset of ISO 8601 in the proposal. Also Micah is no longer an EIP editor.

author: samwilsn
content: Hm, looks like not all ISO standards have DOI numbers...

author: samwilsn
content: We'll need to add a new exception for ISOs.

author: kdenhartog
content: Ahh, I'll suggest to them that we just use this RFC instead: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3339#appendix-A

author: kdenhartog
content: And yeah main reason I tagged Micah was just because he had strong opinions on this originally when it was banned

author: kdenhartog
content:
The alternative definition we could use is: https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#isoformats

Main reason things like this matter is to prevent issues like this from popping up: https://github.com/w3c/vc-data-model/issues/782

author: pandapip1
content: I really feel like we should not be allowing paid specs.

author: samwilsn
content:
Yeah, the exact requirement from EIP-1 I'd copy for ISO standards is:

> The top-level URL field must resolve to a copy of the referenced document which can be viewed at zero cost.

So perhaps a preprint, or sci hub or something.
